trans-unit.source: Deploy and configure a SaaS connector API app
trans-unit.target: Deploy and configure a SaaS connector API app

trans-unit.source: Learn how to configure a SaaS connector that you install in your Azure subscription from the Azure Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to configure a SaaS connector that you install in your Azure subscription from the Azure Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to install, configure, and test a <linkText>Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) connector</linkText><title></title> in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> for calling it programmatically, such as from a mobile app.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to install, configure, and test a <linkText>Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) connector</linkText><title></title> in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> for calling it programmatically, such as from a mobile app.

trans-unit.source: A SaaS connector is an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> that simplifies interaction with a SaaS platform such as Office 365, Salesforce, Facebook, and Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: A SaaS connector is an <linkText>API app</linkText><title></title> that simplifies interaction with a SaaS platform such as Office 365, Salesforce, Facebook, and Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: If instead of using a prepackaged connector you want to create a custom .NET API app, see <linkText>Connect to a SaaS platform from an ASP.NET API app</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If instead of using a prepackaged connector you want to create a custom .NET API app, see <linkText>Connect to a SaaS platform from an ASP.NET API app</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to code HTTP requests to read and write files in your Dropbox account, the authentication process for working directly with Dropbox is complicated.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to code HTTP requests to read and write files in your Dropbox account, the authentication process for working directly with Dropbox is complicated.

trans-unit.source: A Dropbox connector takes care of the complexity of authentication so that you can focus on writing your business-specific code.
trans-unit.target: A Dropbox connector takes care of the complexity of authentication so that you can focus on writing your business-specific code.

trans-unit.source: The instructions here are not required if you want to use a SaaS connector from a logic app. For information about how to use SaaS connectors inside logic apps, see <linkText>Create a new logic app</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Using custom OAUTH Application in Connectors</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The instructions here are not required if you want to use a SaaS connector from a logic app. For information about how to use SaaS connectors inside logic apps, see <linkText>Create a new logic app</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Using custom OAUTH Application in Connectors</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses a DropBox connector as an example and walks you through the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses a DropBox connector as an example and walks you through the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Install the Dropbox connector in a <linkText>resource group</linkText><title></title> in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Install the Dropbox connector in a <linkText>resource group</linkText><title></title> in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Dropbox connector so that it can connect to the Dropbox service.
trans-unit.target: Configure the Dropbox connector so that it can connect to the Dropbox service.

trans-unit.source: (To complete this step you'll need a Dropbox account.)
trans-unit.target: (To complete this step you'll need a Dropbox account.)

trans-unit.source: Configure the resource group so that only authenticated users can access API apps that are included in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Configure the resource group so that only authenticated users can access API apps that are included in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Test to verify that both user authentication and Dropbox authentication work.
trans-unit.target: Test to verify that both user authentication and Dropbox authentication work.

trans-unit.source: For more information about authentication in App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about authentication in App Service, see <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Go to the [Azure preview portal] home page and click Marketplace.
trans-unit.target: Go to the [Azure preview portal] home page and click Marketplace.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Marketplace in Azure preview portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Marketplace in Azure preview portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Search for Dropbox, and then click the Dropbox Connector icon.
trans-unit.target: Search for Dropbox, and then click the Dropbox Connector icon.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Dropbox Connector</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Dropbox Connector</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Create</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Create</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Dropbox Connector blade, under App Service plan click Create New, and then in the Create new App Service plan box enter DropBoxPlan.
trans-unit.target: In the Dropbox Connector blade, under App Service plan click Create New, and then in the Create new App Service plan box enter DropBoxPlan.

trans-unit.source: For more information about App Service plans, see <linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about App Service plans, see <linkText>Azure App Service plans in-depth overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Under Resource Group, click Create New, and then in the Create New Resource Group box enter DropboxRG.
trans-unit.target: Under Resource Group, click Create New, and then in the Create New Resource Group box enter DropboxRG.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource groups, see <linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource groups, see <linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Select the Free Pricing Tier.
trans-unit.target: Select the Free Pricing Tier.

trans-unit.source: (If you don't see it in the list, click View All.
trans-unit.target: (If you don't see it in the list, click View All.

trans-unit.source: After you click F1 Free, click the Select button.)
trans-unit.target: After you click F1 Free, click the Select button.)

trans-unit.source: You can use a paid pricing tier, but it isn't required for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You can use a paid pricing tier, but it isn't required for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Choose a Location close to you.
trans-unit.target: Choose a Location close to you.

trans-unit.source: Keep the default "DropboxConnector" as the Name of the connector, and then click Create.
trans-unit.target: Keep the default "DropboxConnector" as the Name of the connector, and then click Create.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click create</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click create</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service creates a resource group, and in the resource group it creates a Dropbox connector API app, and a gateway web app.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service creates a resource group, and in the resource group it creates a Dropbox connector API app, and a gateway web app.

trans-unit.source: The gateway's function is to manage access to all API apps in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The gateway's function is to manage access to all API apps in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: You can check the progress of resource creation by clicking Notifications on the Azure preview portal home page.
trans-unit.target: You can check the progress of resource creation by clicking Notifications on the Azure preview portal home page.

trans-unit.source: When Azure finishes creating the connector, click Browse > Resource groups > DropboxRG.
trans-unit.target: When Azure finishes creating the connector, click Browse > Resource groups > DropboxRG.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Group blade for DropboxRG shows the connector and the gateway in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Group blade for DropboxRG shows the connector and the gateway in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource group diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource group diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To enable API access to your Dropbox account, you have to create a Dropbox app on the Dropbox developer site.
trans-unit.target: To enable API access to your Dropbox account, you have to create a Dropbox app on the Dropbox developer site.

trans-unit.source: Then you copy the client ID and client secret values from that Dropbox app to your Dropbox connector, and you set the connector to accept only authenticated requests.
trans-unit.target: Then you copy the client ID and client secret values from that Dropbox app to your Dropbox connector, and you set the connector to accept only authenticated requests.

trans-unit.source: By default the connector's Access level is set to Internal, meaning it can only be called by other API apps and web apps in the same resource group.
trans-unit.target: By default the connector's Access level is set to Internal, meaning it can only be called by other API apps and web apps in the same resource group.

trans-unit.source: But Dropbox allows only authenticated users to access your Dropbox account, so you have to change the access level setting to require user authentication.
trans-unit.target: But Dropbox allows only authenticated users to access your Dropbox account, so you have to change the access level setting to require user authentication.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the Settings blade, and click Application settings.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the Settings blade, and click Application settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Application settings blade, set Access level to Public (authenticated), and then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the Application settings blade, set Access level to Public (authenticated), and then click Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set to Public (authenticated)</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set to Public (authenticated)</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You have now configured the Dropbox Connector so that outgoing calls can access your Dropbox account, and incoming calls must be from authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: You have now configured the Dropbox Connector so that outgoing calls can access your Dropbox account, and incoming calls must be from authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: In the next section you specify which authentication provider you want to use to authenticate users.
trans-unit.target: In the next section you specify which authentication provider you want to use to authenticate users.

trans-unit.source: As explained <linkText>earlier</linkText><title></title>, the gateway is a special web app that manages access to all API apps in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: As explained <linkText>earlier</linkText><title></title>, the gateway is a special web app that manages access to all API apps in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: To set up the gateway to authenticate users, you choose an authentication provider such as Azure Active Directory, Google, or Twitter.
trans-unit.target: To set up the gateway to authenticate users, you choose an authentication provider such as Azure Active Directory, Google, or Twitter.

trans-unit.source: Users will then have to authenticate with the chosen provider before they can successfully call the Dropbox connector.
trans-unit.target: Users will then have to authenticate with the chosen provider before they can successfully call the Dropbox connector.

trans-unit.source: To perform this step, go to the <linkText>Configure the gateway</linkText><title></title> section of the <linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorial, and follow the directions there to configure the gateway in your DropboxRG resource group.
trans-unit.target: To perform this step, go to the <linkText>Configure the gateway</linkText><title></title> section of the <linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title> tutorial, and follow the directions there to configure the gateway in your DropboxRG resource group.

trans-unit.source: After you have configured the gateway in your DropboxRG resource group to use an authentication provider, you can test your Dropbox connector.
trans-unit.target: After you have configured the gateway in your DropboxRG resource group to use an authentication provider, you can test your Dropbox connector.

trans-unit.source: Most of the time you'll use a connector by calling it from code, and we're also writing tutorials that will show how to do that.
trans-unit.target: Most of the time you'll use a connector by calling it from code, and we're also writing tutorials that will show how to do that.

trans-unit.source: But sometimes you'll want to validate that the connector is working before wiring up other parts of an app.
trans-unit.target: But sometimes you'll want to validate that the connector is working before wiring up other parts of an app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to use a browser and a simple REST client tool to verify that you can interact with the Dropbox service through the Dropbox connector that you just installed and configured.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to use a browser and a simple REST client tool to verify that you can interact with the Dropbox service through the Dropbox connector that you just installed and configured.

trans-unit.source: The following instructions show how to do these steps by using the Chrome browser developer tools and Postman REST client tool.
trans-unit.target: The following instructions show how to do these steps by using the Chrome browser developer tools and Postman REST client tool.

trans-unit.source: This is just an example, and you can do the same procedures with other browsers and tools.
trans-unit.target: This is just an example, and you can do the same procedures with other browsers and tools.

trans-unit.source: "Advanced REST Client" is another Chrome add-in you can use.
trans-unit.target: "Advanced REST Client" is another Chrome add-in you can use.

trans-unit.source: Do the following steps in a new browser window.
trans-unit.target: Do the following steps in a new browser window.

trans-unit.source: Depending on what authentication provider you're using, you might find that you need to use a private or incognito window.
trans-unit.target: Depending on what authentication provider you're using, you might find that you need to use a private or incognito window.

trans-unit.source: Go to the login URL for the gateway and the authentication provider that you configured.
trans-unit.target: Go to the login URL for the gateway and the authentication provider that you configured.

trans-unit.source: The URL follows this pattern:
trans-unit.target: The URL follows this pattern:

trans-unit.source: You can get the gateway URL from the Gateway blade in the [Azure preview portal].
trans-unit.target: You can get the gateway URL from the Gateway blade in the [Azure preview portal].

trans-unit.source: (To get to the Gateway blade, click the gateway in the diagram shown on the Resource group blade.)
trans-unit.target: (To get to the Gateway blade, click the gateway in the diagram shown on the Resource group blade.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Gateway URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Gateway URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The [providername] value is "facebook" for Facebook, "twitter" for Twitter, "aad" for Azure Active directory, etc.
trans-unit.target: The [providername] value is "facebook" for Facebook, "twitter" for Twitter, "aad" for Azure Active directory, etc.

trans-unit.source: Here is a sample login URL for Azure Active Directory:
trans-unit.target: Here is a sample login URL for Azure Active Directory:

trans-unit.source: Enter your credentials when the browser displays a login page.
trans-unit.target: Enter your credentials when the browser displays a login page.

trans-unit.source: If you configured Azure Active Directory login, log in as one of the users listed in the Users tab for the application you created in the Azure Active Directory tab of the [Azure portal], such as admin@contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
trans-unit.target: If you configured Azure Active Directory login, log in as one of the users listed in the Users tab for the application you created in the Azure Active Directory tab of the [Azure portal], such as admin@contoso.onmicrosoft.com.

trans-unit.source: When login is successful, you get a "Login complete" page.
trans-unit.target: When login is successful, you get a "Login complete" page.

trans-unit.source: To get Dropbox authorization to use the Dropbox API, you have to provide the user's credentials to Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: To get Dropbox authorization to use the Dropbox API, you have to provide the user's credentials to Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: Azure will initiate that process for you, but to trigger that process you have to go to a special gateway URL in the browser.
trans-unit.target: Azure will initiate that process for you, but to trigger that process you have to go to a special gateway URL in the browser.

trans-unit.source: To get that URL you make an HTTP Post request to the gateway.
trans-unit.target: To get that URL you make an HTTP Post request to the gateway.

trans-unit.source: The HTTP Post request to the gateway has to include the authentication token that Azure provided when you logged in.
trans-unit.target: The HTTP Post request to the gateway has to include the authentication token that Azure provided when you logged in.

trans-unit.source: For browser requests, including the token is automatic because the token is stored in a cookie, but for an HTTP Post request using a REST client tool you have to get the token from the cookie and put it in the request header of the HTTP Post request.
trans-unit.target: For browser requests, including the token is automatic because the token is stored in a cookie, but for an HTTP Post request using a REST client tool you have to get the token from the cookie and put it in the request header of the HTTP Post request.

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that has the "Login complete" message, go to the browser's developer tools and find the x-zumo-auth cookie.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that has the "Login complete" message, go to the browser's developer tools and find the x-zumo-auth cookie.

trans-unit.source: Keep this window open so you can copy the value of the cookie in the next step.
trans-unit.target: Keep this window open so you can copy the value of the cookie in the next step.

trans-unit.source: To get the cookie value in Chrome, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To get the cookie value in Chrome, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Press F12 to open developer tools.
trans-unit.target: Press F12 to open developer tools.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Resources tab.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Resources tab.

trans-unit.source: Find the cookies for your gateway site, and triple-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie to select all of it.
trans-unit.target: Find the cookies for your gateway site, and triple-click the Value of the x-zumo-auth cookie to select all of it.

trans-unit.source: (Make sure you get all of the cookie's value.
trans-unit.target: (Make sure you get all of the cookie's value.

trans-unit.source: If you double-click, you might get only the first part of it.)
trans-unit.target: If you double-click, you might get only the first part of it.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Copy token</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Copy token</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In a new browser tab or window, create and send an HTTP Post request to the gateway to request a consent URL.
trans-unit.target: In a new browser tab or window, create and send an HTTP Post request to the gateway to request a consent URL.

trans-unit.source: Include the x-zumo-auth token as an HTTP header.
trans-unit.target: Include the x-zumo-auth token as an HTTP header.

trans-unit.source: The URL follows this pattern:
trans-unit.target: The URL follows this pattern:

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: To send the request in Postman in Chrome, perform the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To send the request in Postman in Chrome, perform the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Enter the Request URL described above.
trans-unit.target: Enter the Request URL described above.

trans-unit.source: Set the method to Post.
trans-unit.target: Set the method to Post.

trans-unit.source: Add a header named x-zumo-auth.
trans-unit.target: Add a header named x-zumo-auth.

trans-unit.source: In the header Value field paste the value you copied from the x-zumo-auth cookie.
trans-unit.target: In the header Value field paste the value you copied from the x-zumo-auth cookie.

trans-unit.source: Click Send.
trans-unit.target: Click Send.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows the Postman tool in Chrome:
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows the Postman tool in Chrome:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Send for consent URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Send for consent URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The response includes a URL to use in order to initiate the process of logging in the user with Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: The response includes a URL to use in order to initiate the process of logging in the user with Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: (If you get an error response that indicates the Get method is not supported although you have the method dropdown set to Post, make sure that your gateway URL is HTTPS, not HTTP.)
trans-unit.target: (If you get an error response that indicates the Get method is not supported although you have the method dropdown set to Post, make sure that your gateway URL is HTTPS, not HTTP.)

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Consent URL</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Consent URL</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Go to the URL that you received in response to the HTTP Post request.
trans-unit.target: Go to the URL that you received in response to the HTTP Post request.

trans-unit.source: The response to this URL redirects the browser to the Dropbox site, where the user logs in and grants consent for the app to access the user's account.
trans-unit.target: The response to this URL redirects the browser to the Dropbox site, where the user logs in and grants consent for the app to access the user's account.

trans-unit.source: When the login and consent process is done, Dropbox redirects the browser to the redirect URL that you specified (e.g., the Azure preview portal if you followed the example and used https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: When the login and consent process is done, Dropbox redirects the browser to the redirect URL that you specified (e.g., the Azure preview portal if you followed the example and used https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: If you were calling from a web app, this would be the next page to be displayed in the web app.
trans-unit.target: If you were calling from a web app, this would be the next page to be displayed in the web app.

trans-unit.source: The app should check the URL, because if there was an error in the login or consent process, the redirect URL could include an error querystring variable.
trans-unit.target: The app should check the URL, because if there was an error in the login or consent process, the redirect URL could include an error querystring variable.

trans-unit.source: Keep this browser window open, as you'll use it in the following section.
trans-unit.target: Keep this browser window open, as you'll use it in the following section.

trans-unit.source: Azure is now managing three authentication tokens for you:
trans-unit.target: Azure is now managing three authentication tokens for you:

trans-unit.source: One from the authentication provider you configured for the gateway, for example Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: One from the authentication provider you configured for the gateway, for example Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: One from Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: One from Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: One that Azure creates (the "zumo" token).
trans-unit.target: One that Azure creates (the "zumo" token).

trans-unit.source: The only one you have to use when making HTTP requests to work with Dropbox is the zumo token.
trans-unit.target: The only one you have to use when making HTTP requests to work with Dropbox is the zumo token.

trans-unit.source: Behind the scenes Azure has associated that token with the other two, and the connector provides the other two on your behalf when it makes calls to Dropbox.
trans-unit.target: Behind the scenes Azure has associated that token with the other two, and the connector provides the other two on your behalf when it makes calls to Dropbox.

trans-unit.source: In the following steps you make a Get request to the Dropbox connector to look at files in your Dropbox account.
trans-unit.target: In the following steps you make a Get request to the Dropbox connector to look at files in your Dropbox account.

trans-unit.source: Since you can use a browser window for a Get request, and since your browser window already has the zumo token in a cookie, all you have to do is go to a URL and you get back Dropbox data.
trans-unit.target: Since you can use a browser window for a Get request, and since your browser window already has the zumo token in a cookie, all you have to do is go to a URL and you get back Dropbox data.

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that has the Azure preview portal open, go back to the API App blade for your Dropbox connector.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that has the Azure preview portal open, go back to the API App blade for your Dropbox connector.

trans-unit.source: Copy the API app's URL.
trans-unit.target: Copy the API app's URL.

trans-unit.source: Click the API definition icon to see the API methods available in the connector.
trans-unit.target: Click the API definition icon to see the API methods available in the connector.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API App blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>API definition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>API definition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the browser window that you used to authenticate to the gateway, call the GET method that retrieves file names from a folder.
trans-unit.target: In the browser window that you used to authenticate to the gateway, call the GET method that retrieves file names from a folder.

trans-unit.source: Here is the URL pattern:
trans-unit.target: Here is the URL pattern:

trans-unit.source: For example, if your connector URL is https://dropboxrg784237ad3e7.azurewebsites.net and you want to see the files in your blog folder, the URL would be:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your connector URL is https://dropboxrg784237ad3e7.azurewebsites.net and you want to see the files in your blog folder, the URL would be:

trans-unit.source: Different browsers respond to API calls differently; if you're using Chrome you'll see a response similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: Different browsers respond to API calls differently; if you're using Chrome you'll see a response similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Get response to folder request</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Get response to folder request</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You've seen how to install, configure, and test a SaaS connector.
trans-unit.target: You've seen how to install, configure, and test a SaaS connector.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see these resources:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see these resources:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Using connectors</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Using connectors</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: https://portal.azure.com/
trans-unit.target: https://portal.azure.com/

trans-unit.source: https://manage.windowsazure.com/
trans-unit.target: https://manage.windowsazure.com/
